cyber.xsd

<xs:schema
  targetNamespace="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/domains/cyber/6.0/"
  version="ps02"
  xml:lang="en-US"
  xsi:schemaLocation="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/appinfo/6.0/ ../utility/appinfo.xsd https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/specification/conformanceTargets/6.0/ ../utility/conformanceTargets.xsd"
  ct:conformanceTargets="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/specification/XNDR/6.0/#ReferenceSchemaDocument"
  xmlns:appinfo="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/appinfo/6.0/"
  xmlns:ct="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/specification/conformanceTargets/6.0/"
  xmlns:cyber="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/domains/cyber/6.0/"
  xmlns:ip="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/domains/infrastructureProtection/6.0/"
  xmlns:nc="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/niem-core/6.0/"
  xmlns:niem-xs="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/adapters/niem-xs/6.0/"
  xmlns:stix="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/codes/stix/6.0/"
  xmlns:structures="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/structures/6.0/"
  xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
  xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
  <xs:annotation>
    <xs:documentation>Cyber</xs:documentation>
    <xs:appinfo>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="CPS" literal="Cyber-Physical System" definition="A system that incorporates the interaction of digital, analog, physical, and human components engineered for function through integrated physics and logic."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="CVE" literal="Common Vulnerability Enumeration" definition="A category system for hardware and software weaknesses and vulnerabilities."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="DHCP" literal="Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol" definition="A method to provide quick and centralized management of IP addresses and other TCP/IP settings on your network."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="DNS" literal="Domain Name System"/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="Exfiltrated" literal="Exfiltrated" definition="Data or information that was surreptitiously withdrawn from a location without permission."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="Exfiltration" literal="Exfiltration" definition="A method of surreptitiously withdrawing data or information from a location without permission."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="FISMA" literal="Federal Information Security Modernization Act"/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="IOA" literal="Indicator(s) of Attack" definition="Evidence of the intent the adversary is trying to accomplish."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="IOB" literal="Indicator(s) of Behavior" definition="Evidence of user behavior and interests."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="IOC" literal="Indicator(s) of Compromise" definition="Forensic evidence of potential intrusions on a host system or network."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="SBOM" literal="Software Bill of Materials" definition="A SBOM is a nested inventory, a list of ingredients that make up software components. ref cisa.gov/sbom"/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="SMS" literal="Short Messaging Service" definition="A technology for sending short text messages between mobile phones"/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="TTP" literal="Tactic, Technique, and Procedure" definition="A description of the "why," "how," and specific implementation the adversary uses."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="VERIS" literal="Vocabulary for Event Recording and Incident Sharing" definition="The Vocabulary for Event Recording and Incident Sharing (VERIS) is a set of metrics designed to provide a common language for describing security incidents in a structured and repeatable manner."/>
      <appinfo:LocalTerm term="WFN" literal="well-formed CPE name"/>
    </xs:appinfo>
  </xs:annotation>
  <xs:import namespace="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/adapters/niem-xs/6.0/" schemaLocation="../adapters/niem-xs.xsd"/>
  <xs:import namespace="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/codes/stix/6.0/" schemaLocation="../codes/stix.xsd"/>
  <xs:import namespace="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/domains/infrastructureProtection/6.0/" schemaLocation="infrastructureProtection.xsd"/>
  <xs:import namespace="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/niem-core/6.0/" schemaLocation="../niem-core.xsd"/>
  <xs:import namespace="https://docs.oasis-open.org/niemopen/ns/model/structures/6.0/" schemaLocation="../utility/structures.xsd"/>
  <xs:simpleType name="AccessedInformationCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of information that has been or potentially has been accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Academic and Professional Background Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Academic and Professional Background Information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="access code">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A series of numbers and/or letters that allow access to a particular system</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="account number">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A unique string of numbers and, sometimes, letters and other characters that identifies the owner of an account and grants access to it</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="ACH payment information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information regarding an electronic funds-transfer system that facilitates payments in the U.S.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Alias (i.e., username or screenname)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Alias (i.e., username or screenname) information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Alien Registration Number">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Alien Registration Number has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="alleged criminal activity">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An illegal action or activity for which a person can be punished by law that has not been proven true.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="asset information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information about a useful or valuable thing, person, or quality.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Birth certificate">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An official document issued to record a person's birth, including such identifying data as name, gender, date of birth, place of birth, and parentage</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="broker account number">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A specific identifier for an investment account that allows you to buy and sell a variety of investments, such as stocks, bonds, mutual funds, and ET.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Bank Account Number (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Bank Account Number (sole proprietor) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Credit Card Number (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Credit Card Number (sole proprietor) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Device Identifiers or Serial Numbers (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Device Identifiers or Serial Numbers (sole proprietor) have been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Email Address">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Email Address information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Financial Information (including loan information)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Financial Information (including loan information) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Mailing Address (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Mailing Address (sole proprietor) information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Mobile Number (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Mobile Number (sole proprietor) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Phone or Fax Number (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Phone or Fax Number (sole proprietor) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Taxpayer Identification Number (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Taxpayer Identification Number (sole proprietor) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Business Vehicle Identification Number (sole proprietor)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Business Vehicle Identification Number (sole proprietor) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="cardholder statements">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A summary of how you've used your credit card for a billing period.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Case Files">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Case Files have been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="cash position">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Represents the amount of cash that a company, investment fund, or bank has on its books at a specific point in time</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Cell Tower Records (i.e., logs, user location, time, etc.)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Cell Tower Record (i.e., logs, user location, time, etc.) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="certificate/license number">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Birth certificate number, etc.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Certification of Birth Abroad">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A document that certifies a child acquired U.S. citizenship at birth</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Children Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Children Information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Citizenship">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Citizenship information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="City or County of Birth">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>City or County of Birth information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Civil/Criminal History Information/Police Record">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Civil/Criminal History Information/Police Record has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="claim number">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A unique identifying code assigned to each claim by the insurer</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="client information, including unique client identifier (UCI)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information for a person or organization using the services of a lawyer or other professional person or company</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="cookie information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A packet of data sent by a web server to a browser, which is returned by the browser each time it subsequently accesses the same server, used to identify the user or track their access to the server.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="copay information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Specific details regarding a payment made by a beneficiary (especially for health services) in addition to that made by an insurer.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="correspondence">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Communication by exchanging letters with someone.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Country of Birth">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Country of Birth information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="CPT code">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A uniform language for coding medical services and procedures to streamline reporting, increase accuracy and efficiency</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="credit card expiration date">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Usually three years after the card is first activated, and you can use the card without interruption through the end of the listed month</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="credit card security code /CVV2/CCV/CVV/CAV2">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Usually a 3 - or 4 - digit number, which is not part of the credit card number</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Credit History Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Credit History Information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Credit/Debit Card Number">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Credit/Debit Card Number has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) suspect information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) suspect information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="cryptocurrency or virtual currency transaction information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information stored on a blockchain that provides details of a specific transaction</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="cryptocurrency or virtual currency wallet information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information regarding a specific cryptocurrency wallet</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Date of Birth (Day, Month, Year)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Date of Birth information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="date of death information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The date that a person is pronounced dead by a physician, coroner, deputy coroner, medical examiner, deputy medical examiner, or hospice nurse</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="date of enrollment">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The effective date of coverage or, if earlier, the first day of the waiting period for such coverage</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="deductible payments">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The amount you pay for covered health care services before your insurance plan starts to pay</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="demographic information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Socioeconomic information expressed statistically, including employment, education, income, marriage rates, birth and death rates, and more</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Dental Profile">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Dental Profile has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>

        <xs:annotation>

        </xs:annotation>

        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>

        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>

      <xs:enumeration value="Vehicle Identification Number">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Vehicle Identification Number has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="veteran status">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The current state for a person who has served in the military.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Video Recording">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Video Recording has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Visa information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information about a conditional authorization granted by a polity to a foreigner that allows them to enter, remain within, or to leave a territory</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Voice/Audio Recording">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Voice/Audio Recording has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="W-2 information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Reflects your income earned and taxes withheld from the prior year to be reported on your income tax returns</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Web URLs">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An acronym for Uniform Resource Locator and is a reference (an address) to a resource on the Internet</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Weight">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Weight information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Workers’ Compensation Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Workers’ Compensation Information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="x-rays">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A photographic or digital image of the internal composition of something, especially a part of the body, produced by X-rays being passed through it and being absorbed to different degrees by different materials</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Zip Code">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Zip Code information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="AccessedInformationCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of information that has been or potentially has been accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:AccessedInformationCodeSimpleType">
        <xs:attributeGroup ref="structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="AdversaryCommunicationType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a communication from an adversary during an incident.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:ExtortionCommunicationDetails" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:AdversaryCommunicationAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="AttackPatternType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a behavior that attackers use to carry out their attacks. It is considered a type of tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:AttackPatternName" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:AttackPatternDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:KillChainPhase" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:AttackPatternAliasText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:AttackPatternAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="AttackVectorCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of general approach to achieving an effect, which takes advantage of the exposure of a kind of, or a region in, an attack surface</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Account Takeover">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A form of identity theft and fraud, where a malicious third party successfully gains access to a user's account credentials.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Attrition">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An attack that employs brute force methods to compromise, degrade, or destroy systems, networks, or services</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Email/Phishing">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An attack executed via an email message or attachment</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="External/Removable Media">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An attack executed from removable media or a peripheral device</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Impersonation/Spoofing">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An attack involving replacement of legitimate content/services with a malicious substitute</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Improper Usage">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An incident resulting from violation of an organization’s acceptable usage policies by an authorized user</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Loss or Theft of Equipment">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The loss or theft of a computing device or media used by the organization</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Other">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An attack approach that has not been previously specified</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Unknown">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The attack approach is not known</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Web">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An attack executed from a website or web-based application</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>

  <xs:simpleType name="BackupAvailableCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a type of back-up available.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Differential">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A differential back-up with data modified since the last full back-up.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Full">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A full back-up.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Hybrid">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>More than one of the back-up types are available and required to produce a full restore.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Incremental">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An incremental back-up with data modified since the last back-up.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Other">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A different type of back-up is available.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>

  </xs:complexType>

  <xs:simpleType name="BreachClassificationCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of category of information that has been or potentially has been accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Attorney - Client privileged information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information pertaining to privileged communications between attorneys and clients.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Biographical Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Biographical Information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Biometrics, Distinguishing Features, and Characteristics">
        <xs:annotation>

        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Credit Card Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Credit Card or other Information protected under the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) that has been or potentially has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Device Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Device Information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Evidence Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Evidence in a law enforcement investigation that has been or potentially has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Export controlled information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information that is restricted from being exported or otherwise provided to certain individuals, companies, or countries.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Financial Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Financial Information protected under Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act that has been or potentially has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Identifying Numbers">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Identifying Numbers have been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Information related to critical infrastructure security">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Protected Critical Infrastructure Information (PCII) has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Information related to minors">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Minor’s information protected under the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) that has been or potentially has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Jurisdiction Specific protected information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information protected by tribal, regional, and/or local laws that has been or potentially has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Medical and Emergency Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Medical and Emergency Information has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Other Specific Information or File Types">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Other Specific Information or File Types have been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Sensitive identifiable human subject research data">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information that identifies human subjects in research projects.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Student Information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Student grade information protected under Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) that has been or potentially has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Student loan information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Financial information related to student loans.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Suspect identitying information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Criminal Justice Information System protected information that has been or potentially has been accessed, potentially accessed, manipulated, destroyed, or rendered unusable as a result of a compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Tax Information">
        <xs:annotation>

        </xs:annotation>

    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>

  <xs:simpleType name="BreachEffectCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of effect on information resulting from a breach</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Compromise Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Unauthorized access of Information was due to compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Loss 100000 or More People">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information for 100,000 or more people was exfiltrated, modified, deleted, or compromised</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Loss Of Control Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Unauthorized access of Information was due to loss of control</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Unauthorized Access">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information was accessed without authorization</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Unauthorized Acquisition Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Unauthorized access of Information was due to unauthorized acquisition</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Unauthorized Disclosure Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Unauthorized access of Information was due to unauthorized disclosure</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Unauthorized Person">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information was accessed by a person other than an authorized user</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Unauthorized Purpose">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information was accessed for an unauthorized purpose</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="BreachEffectCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of effect on information resulting from a breach</xs:documentation>

    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>

          <xs:element ref="cyber:BreachAlteredQuantityCategoryCode" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:BreachEffectCode" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:BreachExposedHealthInformationOver500Indicator" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="BreachExposedFileType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a file exposed in a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:FileCategoryName" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:BreachExposedFileQuantity" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:ClassifiedInformationExposure" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:DataClassification" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:BreachExposedFileAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="BreachNotificationMethodCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a method by which an individual is notified of a breach</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Automated Machine-to-Machine Method">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via an automated machine-to-machine method (e.g. STIX/TAXII)</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Email">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via email</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Hybrid">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via a combination of methods.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="In-person">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach in-person.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Non-verbal telecommunications platform">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via a non-verbal telecommunications platform (e.g. Slack, threat intelligence platform, etc.)</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Online reporting form">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via an online reporting form</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Other">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via other means</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Parcel">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via parcel (e.g. USPS, FexEx, UPS)</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="SMS">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via SMS</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Telephone call">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was notified of a breach via a telephone call</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Verbal">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An entity was verbally notified of a breach</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>

  <xs:simpleType name="BreachRegulationCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of information protected by law, regulation, or other restriction that was accessed or potentially accessed in a breach.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) protected information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) protected information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>

        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>

        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>

        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act protected information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act protected information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Jurisdiction specifically protected information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of tribally, locally, and/or regionally protected information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Non-cyber related Personally Identifiable Information (PII)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Personally Identifiable Information as a result of a non-cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Other">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>a breach of information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Payment Card Industry (PCI) protected information">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) protected information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Protected Critical Infrastructure Information (PCII)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Protected Critical Infrastructure Information (PCII) information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Protected Health Information (PHI)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of Protected Health Information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Tax information - federal or other">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A breach of protected tax information as a result of a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>

    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberAnalyticDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:AttackPattern" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberAnalyticProgrammingStatement" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:Platform" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberAnalyticAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="CyberEnterpriseSubTechniqueCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of specific representation for an enterprise sub-technique that describes 'how' an adversary achieves a tactical goal by performing an action.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="T1001.001 - Junk Data">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may add junk data to protocols used for command and control to make detection more difficult. By adding random or meaningless data to the protocols used for command and control, adversaries can prevent trivial methods for decoding, deciphering, or otherwise analyzing the traffic. Examples may include appending/prepending data with junk characters or writing junk characters between significant characters.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1001.002 - Steganography">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use steganographic techniques to hide command and control traffic to make detection efforts more difficult. Steganographic techniques can be used to hide data in digital messages that are transferred between systems. This hidden information can be used for command and control of compromised systems. In some cases, the passing of files embedded using steganography, such as image or document files, can be used for command and control.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1001.003 - Protocol Impersonation">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may impersonate legitimate protocols or web service traffic to disguise command and control activity and thwart analysis efforts. By impersonating legitimate protocols or web services, adversaries can make their command and control traffic blend in with legitimate network traffic.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.001 - LSASS Memory">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and used to conduct Lateral Movement using Use Alternate Authentication Material.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.002 - Security Account Manager">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to extract credential material from the Security Account Manager (SAM) database either through in-memory techniques or through the Windows Registry where the SAM database is stored. The SAM is a database file that contains local accounts for the host, typically those found with the net user command. Enumerating the SAM database requires SYSTEM level access.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.003 - NTDS">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to access or create a copy of the Active Directory domain database in order to steal credential information, as well as obtain other information about domain members such as devices, users, and access rights. By default, the NTDS file (NTDS.dit) is located in %SystemRoot%\NTDS\Ntds.dit of a domain controller.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.004 - LSA Secrets">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries with SYSTEM access to a host may attempt to access Local Security Authority (LSA) secrets, which can contain a variety of different credential materials, such as credentials for service accounts. LSA secrets are stored in the registry at HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SECURITY\Policy\Secrets. LSA secrets can also be dumped from memory.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.005 - Cached Domain Credentials">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to access cached domain credentials used to allow authentication to occur in the event a domain controller is unavailable.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.006 - DCSync">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to access credentials and other sensitive information by abusing a Windows Domain Controller's application programming interface (API) to simulate the replication process from a remote domain controller using a technique called DCSync.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.007 - Proc Filesystem">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may gather credentials from information stored in the Proc filesystem or /proc. The Proc filesystem on Linux contains a great deal of information regarding the state of the running operating system. Processes running with root privileges can use this facility to scrape live memory of other running programs. If any of these programs store passwords in clear text or password hashes in memory, these values can then be harvested for either usage or brute force attacks, respectively.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1003.008 - /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to dump the contents of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow to enable offline password cracking. Most modern Linux operating systems use a combination of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow to store user account information including password hashes in /etc/shadow. By default, /etc/shadow is only readable by the root user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1011.001 - Exfiltration Over Bluetooth">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to exfiltrate data over Bluetooth rather than the command and control channel. If the command and control network is a wired Internet connection, an attacker may opt to exfiltrate data using a Bluetooth communication channel.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may check for Internet connectivity on compromised systems. This may be performed during automated discovery and can be accomplished in numerous ways such as using Ping, tracert, and GET requests to websites.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1020.001 - Traffic Duplication">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may leverage traffic mirroring in order to automate data exfiltration over compromised network infrastructure. Traffic mirroring is a native feature for some network devices and used for network analysis and may be configured to duplicate traffic and forward to one or more destinations for analysis by a network analyzer or other monitoring device.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to log into a computer using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to interact with a remote network share using Server Message Block (SMB). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1021.003 - Distributed Component Object Model">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to interact with remote machines by taking advantage of Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1021.004 - SSH">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to log into remote machines using Secure Shell (SSH). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1021.005 - VNC">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to remotely control machines using Virtual Network Computing (VNC). VNC is a platform-independent desktop sharing system that uses the RFB ("remote framebuffer") protocol to enable users to remotely control another computer’s display by relaying the screen, mouse, and keyboard inputs over the network.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1021.006 - Windows Remote Management">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to interact with remote systems using Windows Remote Management (WinRM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1027.001 - Binary Padding">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use binary padding to add junk data and change the on-disk representation of malware. This can be done without affecting the functionality or behavior of a binary, but can increase the size of the binary beyond what some security tools are capable of handling due to file size limitations.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1027.002 - Software Packing">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may perform software packing or virtual machine software protection to conceal their code. Software packing is a method of compressing or encrypting an executable. Packing an executable changes the file signature in an attempt to avoid signature-based detection. Most decompression techniques decompress the executable code in memory. Virtual machine software protection translates an executable's original code into a special format that only a special virtual machine can run. A virtual machine is then called to run this code.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1027.003 - Steganography">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use steganography techniques in order to prevent the detection of hidden information. Steganographic techniques can be used to hide data in digital media such as images, audio tracks, video clips, or text files.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1027.004 - Compile After Delivery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to make payloads difficult to discover and analyze by delivering files to victims as uncompiled code. Text-based source code files may subvert analysis and scrutiny from protections targeting executables/binaries. These payloads will need to be compiled before execution; typically via native utilities such as csc.exe or GCC/MinGW.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may remove indicators from tools if they believe their malicious tool was detected, quarantined, or otherwise curtailed. They can modify the tool by removing the indicator and using the updated version that is no longer detected by the target's defensive systems or subsequent targets that may use similar systems.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1027.006 - HTML Smuggling">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may smuggle data and files past content filters by hiding malicious payloads inside of seemingly benign HTML files. HTML documents can store large binary objects known as JavaScript Blobs (immutable data that represents raw bytes) that can later be constructed into file-like objects. Data may also be stored in Data URLs, which enable embedding media type or MIME files inline of HTML documents. HTML5 also introduced a download attribute that may be used to initiate file downloads.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1036.001 - Invalid Code Signature">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to mimic features of valid code signatures to increase the chance of deceiving a user, analyst, or tool. Code signing provides a level of authenticity on a binary from the developer and a guarantee that the binary has not been tampered with. Adversaries can copy the metadata and signature information from a signed program, then use it as a template for an unsigned program. Files with invalid code signatures will fail digital signature validation checks, but they may appear more legitimate to users and security tools may improperly handle these files.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1036.002 - Right-to-Left Override">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse the right-to-left override (RTLO or RLO) character (U+202E) to disguise a string and/or file name to make it appear benign. RTLO is a non-printing Unicode character that causes the text that follows it to be displayed in reverse. For example, a Windows screensaver executable named March 25 \u202Excod.scr will display as March 25 rcs.docx. A JavaScript file named photo_high_re\u202Egnp.js will be displayed as photo_high_resj.png.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may rename legitimate system utilities to try to evade security mechanisms concerning the usage of those utilities. Security monitoring and control mechanisms may be in place for system utilities adversaries are capable of abusing. It may be possible to bypass those security mechanisms by renaming the utility prior to utilization (ex: rename rundll32.exe). An alternative case occurs when a legitimate utility is copied or moved to a different directory and renamed to avoid detections based on system utilities executing from non-standard paths.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to manipulate the name of a task or service to make it appear legitimate or benign. Tasks/services executed by the Task Scheduler or systemd will typically be given a name and/or description. Windows services will have a service name as well as a display name. Many benign tasks and services exist that have commonly associated names. Adversaries may give tasks or services names that are similar or identical to those of legitimate ones.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may match or approximate the name or location of legitimate files or resources when naming/placing them. This is done for the sake of evading defenses and observation. This may be done by placing an executable in a commonly trusted directory (ex: under System32) or giving it the name of a legitimate, trusted program (ex: svchost.exe). In containerized environments, this may also be done by creating a resource in a namespace that matches the naming convention of a container pod or cluster. Alternatively, a file or container image name given may be a close approximation to legitimate programs/images or something innocuous.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1036.006 - Space after Filename">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries can hide a program's true filetype by changing the extension of a file. With certain file types (specifically this does not work with .app extensions), appending a space to the end of a filename will change how the file is processed by the operating system.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1036.007 - Double File Extension">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse a double extension in the filename as a means of masquerading the true file type. A file name may include a secondary file type extension that may cause only the first extension to be displayed (ex: File.txt.exe may render in some views as just File.txt). However, the second extension is the true file type that determines how the file is opened and executed. The real file extension may be hidden by the operating system in the file browser (ex: explorer.exe), as well as in any software configured using or similar to the system’s policies.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1037.001 - Logon Script (Windows)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Windows logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Windows allows logon scripts to be run whenever a specific user or group of users log into a system. This is done via adding a path to a script to the HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript Registry key.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1037.002 - Logon Script (Mac)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use macOS logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. macOS allows logon scripts (known as login hooks) to be executed whenever a specific user logs into a system. A login hook tells Mac OS X to execute a certain script when a user logs in, but unlike Startup Items, a login hook executes as the elevated root user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1037.003 - Network Logon Script">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use network logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Network logon scripts can be assigned using Active Directory or Group Policy Objects. These logon scripts run with the privileges of the user they are assigned to. Depending on the systems within the network, initializing one of these scripts could apply to more than one or potentially all systems.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1037.004 - RC Scripts">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may establish persistence by modifying RC scripts which are executed during a Unix-like system’s startup. These files allow system administrators to map and start custom services at startup for different run levels. RC scripts require root privileges to modify.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1037.005 - Startup Items">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use startup items automatically executed at boot initialization to establish persistence. Startup items execute during the final phase of the boot process and contain shell scripts or other executable files along with configuration information used by the system to determine the execution order for all startup items.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1048.001 - Exfiltration Over Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over a symmetrically encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1048.002 - Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an asymmetrically encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an un-encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1052.001 - Exfiltration over USB">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to exfiltrate data over a USB connected physical device. In certain circumstances, such as an air-gapped network compromise, exfiltration could occur via a USB device introduced by a user. The USB device could be used as the final exfiltration point or to hop between otherwise disconnected systems.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1053.001 - At (Linux)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse the at utility to perform task scheduling for initial, recurring, or future execution of malicious code. The at command within Linux operating systems enables administrators to schedule tasks.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1053.002 - At (Windows)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse the at.exe utility to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. The at utility exists as an executable within Windows for scheduling tasks at a specified time and date. Using at requires that the Task Scheduler service be running, and the user to be logged on as a member of the local Administrators group.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1053.003 - Cron">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse the cron utility to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. The cron utility is a time-based job scheduler for Unix-like operating systems. The crontab file contains the schedule of cron entries to be run and the specified times for execution. Any crontab files are stored in operating system-specific file paths.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1053.004 - Launchd">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>This technique is deprecated due to the inaccurate usage. The report cited did not provide technical detail as to how the malware interacted directly with launchd rather than going through known services. Other system services are used to interact with launchd rather than launchd being used by itself.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1053.005 - Scheduled Task">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. There are multiple ways to access the Task Scheduler in Windows. The schtasks can be run directly on the command line, or the Task Scheduler can be opened through the GUI within the Administrator Tools section of the Control Panel. In some cases, adversaries have used a .NET wrapper for the Windows Task Scheduler, and alternatively, adversaries have used the Windows netapi32 library to create a scheduled task.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1053.006 - Systemd Timers">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse systemd timers to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. Systemd timers are unit files with file extension .timer that control services. Timers can be set to run on a calendar event or after a time span relative to a starting point. They can be used as an alternative to Cron in Linux environments. Systemd timers may be activated remotely via the systemctl command line utility, which operates over SSH.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1053.007 - Container Orchestration Job">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse task scheduling functionality provided by container orchestration tools such as Kubernetes to schedule deployment of containers configured to execute malicious code. Container orchestration jobs run these automated tasks at a specific date and time, similar to cron jobs on a Linux system. Deployments of this type can also be configured to maintain a quantity of containers over time, automating the process of maintaining persistence within a cluster.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. DLL injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.002 - Portable Executable Injection">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject portable executables (PE) into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. PE injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.003 - Thread Execution Hijacking">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into hijacked processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Thread Execution Hijacking is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.004 - Asynchronous Procedure Call">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via the asynchronous procedure call (APC) queue in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. APC injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.005 - Thread Local Storage">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via thread local storage (TLS) callbacks in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. TLS callback injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.008 - Ptrace System Calls">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via ptrace (process trace) system calls in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Ptrace system call injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.009 - Proc Memory">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via the /proc filesystem in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Proc memory injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.011 - Extra Window Memory Injection">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into process via Extra Window Memory (EWM) in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. EWM injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.012 - Process Hollowing">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into suspended and hollowed processes in order to evade process-based defenses. Process hollowing is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.013 - Process Doppelgänging">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into process via process doppelgänging in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Process doppelgänging is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1055.014 - VDSO Hijacking">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via VDSO hijacking in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Virtual dynamic shared object (vdso) hijacking is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1056.001 - Keylogging">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may log user keystrokes to intercept credentials as the user types them. Keylogging is likely to be used to acquire credentials for new access opportunities when OS Credential Dumping efforts are not effective, and may require an adversary to intercept keystrokes on a system for a substantial period of time before credentials can be successfully captured.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may mimic common operating system GUI components to prompt users for credentials with a seemingly legitimate prompt. When programs are executed that need additional privileges than are present in the current user context, it is common for the operating system to prompt the user for proper credentials to authorize the elevated privileges for the task (ex: Bypass User Account Control).</xs:documentation>
