          <xs:documentation>An adversary may capture network traffic to and from the device to obtain credentials or other sensitive data, or redirect network traffic to flow through an adversary-controlled gateway to do the same.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1411 - Input Prompt">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The operating system and installed applications often have legitimate needs to prompt the user for sensitive information such as account credentials, bank account information, or Personally Identifiable Information (PII). Adversaries may mimic this functionality to prompt users for sensitive information.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1412 - Capture SMS Messages">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A malicious application could capture sensitive data sent via SMS, including authentication credentials. SMS is frequently used to transmit codes used for multi-factor authentication.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1413 - Access Sensitive Data in Device Logs">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>On versions of Android prior to 4.1, an adversary may use a malicious application that holds the READ_LOGS permission to obtain private keys, passwords, other credentials, or other sensitive data stored in the device's system log. On Android 4.1 and later, an adversary would need to attempt to perform an operating system privilege escalation attack to be able to access the log.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1414 - Capture Clipboard Data">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse Clipboard Manager APIs to obtain sensitive information copied to the global clipboard. For example, passwords being copy-and-pasted from a password manager app could be captured by another application installed on the device.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1416 - URI Hijacking">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may register Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) to intercept sensitive data.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1417 - Input Capture">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may capture user input to obtain credentials or other information from the user through various methods.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1418 - Application Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may seek to identify all applications installed on the device. One use case for doing so is to identify the presence of endpoint security applications that may increase the adversary's risk of detection. Another use case is to identify the presence of applications that the adversary may wish to target.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1420 - File and Directory Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>On Android, command line tools or the Java file APIs can be used to enumerate file system contents. However, Linux file permissions and SELinux policies generally strongly restrict what can be accessed by apps (without taking advantage of a privilege escalation exploit). The contents of the external storage directory are generally visible, which could present concern if sensitive data is inappropriately stored there.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1421 - System Network Connections Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>On Android, applications can use standard APIs to gather a list of network connections to and from the device. For example, the Network Connections app available in the Google Play Store advertises this functionality.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1422 - System Network Configuration Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>On Android, details of onboard network interfaces are accessible to apps through the java.net.NetworkInterface class. The Android TelephonyManager class can be used to gather related information such as the IMSI, IMEI, and phone number.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1423 - Network Service Scanning">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on remote hosts, including those that may be vulnerable to remote software exploitation. Methods to acquire this information include port scans and vulnerability scans from the mobile device. This technique may take advantage of the mobile device's access to an internal enterprise network either through local connectivity or through a Virtual Private Network (VPN).</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1424 - Process Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>On Android versions prior to 5, applications can observe information about other processes that are running through methods in the ActivityManager class. On Android versions prior to 7, applications can obtain this information by executing the ps command, or by examining the /proc directory. Starting in Android version 7, use of the Linux kernel's hidepid feature prevents applications (without escalated privileges) from accessing this information .</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1426 - System Information Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, and architecture.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1427 - Attack PC via USB Connection">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>With escalated privileges, an adversary could program the mobile device to impersonate USB devices such as input devices (keyboard and mouse), storage devices, and/or networking devices in order to attack a physically connected PC This technique has been demonstrated on Android. We are unaware of any demonstrations on iOS.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1428 - Exploit Enterprise Resources">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to exploit enterprise servers, workstations, or other resources over the network. This technique may take advantage of the mobile device's access to an internal enterprise network either through local connectivity or through a Virtual Private Network (VPN).</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1429 - Capture Audio">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may capture audio to collect information on a user of a mobile device using standard operating system APIs. Adversaries may target audio information such as user conversations, surroundings, phone calls, or other sensitive information.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1430 - Location Tracking">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could use a malicious or exploited application to surreptitiously track the device's physical location through use of standard operating system APIs.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1432 - Access Contact List">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could call standard operating system APIs from a malicious application to gather contact list (i.e., address book) data, or with escalated privileges could directly access files containing contact list data.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1433 - Access Call Log">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>On Android, an adversary could call standard operating system APIs from a malicious application to gather call log data, or with escalated privileges could directly access files containing call log data.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1435 - Access Calendar Entries">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could call standard operating system APIs from a malicious application to gather calendar entry data, or with escalated privileges could directly access files containing calendar data.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1436 - Commonly Used Port">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may communicate over a commonly used port to bypass firewalls or network detection systems and to blend with normal network activity to avoid more detailed inspection.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may communicate using a common, standardized application layer protocol such as HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP, or DNS to avoid detection by blending in with existing traffic.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1438 - Alternate Network Mediums">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries can communicate using cellular networks rather than enterprise Wi-Fi in order to bypass enterprise network monitoring systems. Adversaries may also communicate using other non-Internet Protocol mediums such as SMS, NFC, or Bluetooth to bypass network monitoring systems.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1439 - Eavesdrop on Insecure Network Communication">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>If network traffic between the mobile device and remote servers is unencrypted or is encrypted in an insecure manner, then an adversary positioned on the network can eavesdrop on communication.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could distribute developed malware by masquerading the malware as a legitimate application. This can be done in two different ways: by embedding the malware in a legitimate application, or by pretending to be a legitimate application.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1446 - Device Lockout">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary may seek to lock the legitimate user out of the device, for example to inhibit user interaction or to obtain a ransom payment.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1447 - Delete Device Data">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may wipe a device or delete individual files in order to manipulate external outcomes or hide activity. An application must have administrator access to fully wipe the device, while individual files may not require special permissions to delete depending on their storage location.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1448 - Carrier Billing Fraud">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A malicious app may trigger fraudulent charges on a victim’s carrier billing statement in several different ways, including SMS toll fraud and SMS shortcodes that make purchases.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1449 - Exploit SS7 to Redirect Phone Calls/SMS">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could exploit signaling system vulnerabilities to redirect calls or text messages (SMS) to a phone number under the attacker's control. The adversary could then act as an adversary-in-the-middle to intercept or manipulate the communication. Interception of SMS messages could enable adversaries to obtain authentication codes used for multi-factor authentication.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1450 - Exploit SS7 to Track Device Location">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could exploit signaling system vulnerabilities to track the location of mobile devices.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1451 - SIM Card Swap">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could convince the mobile network operator (e.g. through social networking, forged identification, or insider attacks performed by trusted employees) to issue a new SIM card and associate it with an existing phone number and account. The adversary could then obtain SMS messages or hijack phone calls intended for someone else.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1452 - Manipulate App Store Rankings or Ratings">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could use access to a compromised device's credentials to attempt to manipulate app store rankings or ratings by triggering application downloads or posting fake reviews of applications. This technique likely requires privileged access (a rooted or jailbroken device).</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1456 - Drive-by Compromise">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>As described by Drive-by Compromise, a drive-by compromise is when an adversary gains access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal course of browsing. With this technique, the user's web browser is targeted for exploitation. For example, a website may contain malicious media content intended to exploit vulnerabilities in media parsers as demonstrated by the Android Stagefright vulnerability .</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1458 - Exploit via Charging Station or PC">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>If the mobile device is connected (typically via USB) to a charging station or a PC, for example to charge the device's battery, then a compromised or malicious charging station or PC could attempt to exploit the mobile device via the connection.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1461 - Lockscreen Bypass">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary with physical access to a mobile device may seek to bypass the device's lockscreen.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1463 - Manipulate Device Communication">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>If network traffic between the mobile device and a remote server is not securely protected, then an attacker positioned on the network may be able to manipulate network communication without being detected. For example, FireEye researchers found in 2014 that 68% of the top 1,000 free applications in the Google Play Store had at least one Transport Layer Security (TLS) implementation vulnerability potentially opening the applications' network traffic to adversary-in-the-middle attacks .</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1464 - Jamming or Denial of Service">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An attacker could jam radio signals (e.g. Wi-Fi, cellular, GPS) to prevent the mobile device from communicating.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1465 - Rogue Wi-Fi Access Points">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could set up unauthorized Wi-Fi access points or compromise existing access points and, if the device connects to them, carry out network-based attacks such as eavesdropping on or modifying network communication.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1466 - Downgrade to Insecure Protocols">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could cause the mobile device to use less secure protocols, for example by jamming frequencies used by newer protocols such as LTE and only allowing older protocols such as GSM to communicate. Use of less secure protocols may make communication easier to eavesdrop upon or manipulate.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1467 - Rogue Cellular Base Station">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could set up a rogue cellular base station and then use it to eavesdrop on or manipulate cellular device communication. A compromised cellular femtocell could be used to carry out this technique.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1468 - Remotely Track Device Without Authorization">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary who is able to obtain unauthorized access to or misuse authorized access to cloud services (e.g. Google's Android Device Manager or Apple iCloud's Find my iPhone) or to an enterprise mobility management (EMM) / mobile device management (MDM) server console could use that access to track mobile devices.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1469 - Remotely Wipe Data Without Authorization">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary who is able to obtain unauthorized access to or misuse authorized access to cloud services (e.g. Google's Android Device Manager or Apple iCloud's Find my iPhone) or to an EMM console could use that access to wipe enrolled devices .</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1470 - Obtain Device Cloud Backups">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary who is able to obtain unauthorized access to or misuse authorized access to cloud backup services (e.g. Google's Android backup service or Apple's iCloud) could use that access to obtain sensitive data stored in device backups. For example, the Elcomsoft Phone Breaker product advertises the ability to retrieve iOS backup data from Apple's iCloud . Elcomsoft also describes obtaining WhatsApp communication histories from backups stored in iCloud.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1471 - Data Encrypted for Impact">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary may encrypt files stored on the mobile device to prevent the user from accessing them, for example with the intent of only unlocking access to the files after a ransom is paid. Without escalated privileges, the adversary is generally limited to only encrypting files in external/shared storage locations. This technique has been demonstrated on Android. We are unaware of any demonstrated use on iOS.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1472 - Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could seek to generate fraudulent advertising revenue from mobile devices, for example by triggering automatic clicks of advertising links without user involvement.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1474 - Supply Chain Compromise">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>As further described in Supply Chain Compromise, supply chain compromise is the manipulation of products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise. Somewhat related, adversaries could also identify and exploit inadvertently present vulnerabilities. In many cases, it may be difficult to be certain whether exploitable functionality is due to malicious intent or simply inadvertent mistake.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Malicious applications are a common attack vector used by adversaries to gain a presence on mobile devices. Mobile devices often are configured to allow application installation only from an authorized app store (e.g., Google Play Store or Apple App Store). An adversary may seek to place a malicious application in an authorized app store, enabling the application to be installed onto targeted devices.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Malicious applications are a common attack vector used by adversaries to gain a presence on mobile devices. This technique describes installing a malicious application on targeted mobile devices without involving an authorized app store (e.g., Google Play Store or Apple App Store). Adversaries may wish to avoid placing malicious applications in an authorized app store due to increased potential risk of detection or other reasons. However, mobile devices often are configured to allow application installation only from an authorized app store which would prevent this technique from working.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1477 - Exploit via Radio Interfaces">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The mobile device may be targeted for exploitation through its interface to cellular networks or other radio interfaces.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1478 - Install Insecure or Malicious Configuration">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An adversary could attempt to install insecure or malicious configuration settings on the mobile device, through means such as phishing emails or text messages either directly containing the configuration settings as an attachment, or containing a web link to the configuration settings. The device user may be tricked into installing the configuration settings through social engineering techniques .</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1481 - Web Service">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for relaying commands to a compromised system.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1507 - Network Information Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use device sensors to collect information about nearby networks, such as Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1508 - Suppress Application Icon">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A malicious application could suppress its icon from being displayed to the user in the application launcher to hide the fact that it is installed, and to make it more difficult for the user to uninstall the application. Hiding the application's icon programmatically does not require any special permissions.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1509 - Uncommonly Used Port">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use non-standard ports to exfiltrate information.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1510 - Clipboard Modification">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse clipboard functionality to intercept and replace information in the Android device clipboard. Malicious applications may monitor the clipboard activity through the ClipboardManager.OnPrimaryClipChangedListener interface on Android to determine when the clipboard contents have changed. Listening to clipboard activity, reading the clipboard contents, and modifying the clipboard contents requires no explicit application permissions and can be performed by applications running in the background, however, this behavior has changed with the release of Android 10.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1512 - Capture Camera">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may utilize the camera to capture information about the user, their surroundings, or other physical identifiers. Adversaries may use the physical camera devices on a mobile device to capture images or video. By default, in Android and iOS, an application must request permission to access a camera device which is granted by the user through a request prompt. In Android, applications must hold the android.permission.CAMERA permission to access the camera. In iOS, applications must include the NSCameraUsageDescription key in the Info.plist file, and must request access to the camera at runtime.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1513 - Screen Capture">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use screen captures to collect information about applications running in the foreground, capture user data, credentials, or other sensitive information. Applications running in the background can capture screenshots or videos of another application running in the foreground by using the Android MediaProjectionManager (generally requires the device user to grant consent). Background applications can also use Android accessibility services to capture screen contents being displayed by a foreground application. An adversary with root access or Android Debug Bridge (adb) access could call the Android screencap or screenrecord commands.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1516 - Input Injection">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A malicious application can inject input to the user interface to mimic user interaction through the abuse of Android's accessibility APIs.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1517 - Access Notifications">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A malicious application can read notifications sent by the operating system or other applications, which may contain sensitive data such as one-time authentication codes sent over SMS, email, or other mediums. A malicious application can also dismiss notifications to prevent the user from noticing that the notifications arrived and can trigger action buttons contained within notifications.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1520 - Domain Generation Algorithms">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Domain Generation Algorithms (DGAs) to procedurally generate domain names for command and control communication, and other uses such as malicious application distribution.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1521 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may explicitly employ a known encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Despite the use of a secure algorithm, these implementations may be vulnerable to reverse engineering if necessary secret keys are encoded and/or generated within malware samples/configuration files.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1523 - Evade Analysis Environment">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Malicious applications may attempt to detect their operating environment prior to fully executing their payloads. These checks are often used to ensure the application is not running within an analysis environment such as a sandbox used for application vetting, security research, or reverse engineering. Adversaries may use many different checks such as physical sensors, location, and system properties to fingerprint emulators and sandbox environments. Adversaries may access android.os.SystemProperties via Java reflection to obtain specific system information. Standard values such as phone number, IMEI, IMSI, device IDs, and device drivers may be checked against default signatures of common sandboxes.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1532 - Data Encrypted">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Data is encrypted before being exfiltrated in order to hide the information that is being exfiltrated from detection or to make the exfiltration less conspicuous upon inspection by a defender. The encryption is performed by a utility, programming library, or custom algorithm on the data itself and is considered separate from any encryption performed by the command and control or file transfer protocol. Common file formats that can encrypt files are RAR and zip.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1533 - Data from Local System">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Sensitive data can be collected from local system sources, such as the file system or databases of information residing on the system.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1540 - Code Injection">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use code injection attacks to implant arbitrary code into the address space of a running application. Code is then executed or interpreted by that application. Adversaries utilizing this technique may exploit capabilities to load code in at runtime through dynamic libraries.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1541 - Foreground Persistence">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse Android's startForeground() API method to maintain continuous sensor access. Beginning in Android 9, idle applications running in the background no longer have access to device sensors, such as the camera, microphone, and gyroscope. Applications can retain sensor access by running in the foreground, using Android’s startForeground() API method. This informs the system that the user is actively interacting with the application, and it should not be killed. The only requirement to start a foreground service is showing a persistent notification to the user.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1544 - Remote File Copy">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Files may be copied from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation. Files may be copied from an external adversary-controlled system through the Command and Control channel to bring tools into the victim network or onto the victim’s device.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1575 - Native Code">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use Android’s Native Development Kit (NDK) to write native functions that can achieve execution of binaries or functions. Like system calls on a traditional desktop operating system, native code achieves execution on a lower level than normal Android SDK calls.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1576 - Uninstall Malicious Application">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may include functionality in malware that uninstalls the malicious application from the device.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1577 - Compromise Application Executable">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may modify applications installed on a device to establish persistent access to a victim. These malicious modifications can be used to make legitimate applications carry out adversary tasks when these applications are in use.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1579 - Keychain">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may collect the keychain storage data from an iOS device to acquire credentials. Keychains are the built-in way for iOS to keep track of users' passwords and credentials for many services and features such as Wi-Fi passwords, websites, secure notes, certificates, private keys, and VPN credentials.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1581 - Geofencing">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use a device’s geographical location to limit certain malicious behaviors. For example, malware operators may limit the distribution of a second stage payload to certain geographic regions.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1582 - SMS Control">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may delete, alter, or send SMS messages without user authorization. This could be used to hide C2 SMS messages, spread malware, or various external effects.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1603 - Scheduled Task/Job">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may abuse task scheduling functionality to facilitate initial or recurring execution of malicious code. On Android and iOS, APIs and libraries exist to facilitate scheduling tasks to execute at a specified date, time, or interval.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1604 - Proxy Through Victim">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use a compromised device as a proxy server to the Internet. By utilizing a proxy, adversaries hide the true IP address of their C2 server and associated infrastructure from the destination of the network traffic. This masquerades an adversary’s traffic as legitimate traffic originating from the compromised device, which can evade IP-based restrictions and alerts on certain services, such as bank accounts and social media websites.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1605 - Command-Line Interface">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may use built-in command-line interfaces to interact with the device and execute commands. Android provides a bash shell that can be interacted with over the Android Debug Bridge (ADB) or programmatically using Java’s Runtime package. On iOS, adversaries can interact with the underlying runtime shell if the device has been jailbroken.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1616 - Call Control">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may make, forward, or block phone calls without user authorization. This could be used for adversary goals such as audio surveillance, blocking or forwarding calls from the device owner, or C2 communication.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1617 - Hooking">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may utilize hooking to hide the presence of artifacts associated with their behaviors to evade detection. Hooking can be used to modify return values or data structures of system APIs and function calls. This process typically involves using 3rd party root frameworks, such as Xposed or Magisk, with either a system exploit or pre-existing root access. By including custom modules for root frameworks, adversaries can hook system APIs and alter the return value and/or system data structures to alter functionality/visibility of various aspects of the system.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="T1618 - User Evasion">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Adversaries may attempt to avoid detection by hiding malicious behavior from the user. By doing this, an adversary’s modifications would most likely remain installed on the device for longer, allowing the adversary to continue to operate on that device.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberMobileTechniqueCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of specific representation for a mobile technique that describes 'how' an adversary achieves a tactical goal on a mobile platform by performing an action.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberMobileTechniqueCodeSimpleType">
        <xs:attributeGroup ref="structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="CyberNetworkCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of cyber network.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Campus Area Network (CAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network that spans a limited geographic area.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Enterprise Private Network (EPN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network built by an enterprise to interconnect the sites of the company.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Local Area Network (LAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network at a single site, such as an office.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Metropolitan Area Network (MAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network across an entire city, college campus or small region.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Passive Optical Local Area Network (POLAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network designed to allow a single-mode fiber optic cables across a limited geographic area.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Personal Area Network (PAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network organized around an individual person or family within a single building.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Storage-Area Network (SAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network designed to handle large data transfers and storage.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="System-Area Network (SAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network designed to provide high-performance, connection-oriented performance between a cluster of computers.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A broadcast domain that is partitioned and isolated in a computer network at the data link layer.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Virtual Private Network (VPN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network designed to increase security and privacy.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Wide Area Network (WAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A computer network a very large area, such as an entire country or the entire world.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN)">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A wireless computer network at a single site, such as an office.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberNetworkCategoryCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of cyber network.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberNetworkCategoryCodeSimpleType">
        <xs:attributeGroup ref="structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>

      <xs:documentation>A data type that contains information about a cyber network of connected devices.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkName" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkCategoryCode" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkOwnerPerson" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkOwnerEntity" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkLocation" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkProtectedStatusIndicator" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkIPv4NetworkMaskText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkIPv6NetworkMaskText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkGateway" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkDHCPServer" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkSecurityOwnerPerson" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkSecurityOwnerEntity" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberNetworkAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>

  </xs:complexType>

      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberObservableObjectType">

      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberObservableIPv6AddressObjectType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for an object that represents one or more IPv6 addresses that is the subject of an observation</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberObservableObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableObjectValueText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableDestinationIndicator" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableSourceIndicator" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableIPv6AddressObjectAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberObservableNetworkObjectType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a network object that is the subject of an observation</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberObservableObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableObjectValueText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberObservableNetworkTrafficObjectType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for an object that represents the arbitrary network traffic originating from a source and is addressed to a destination that is the subject of an observation</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberObservableObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:SourcePortID" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableNetworkTrafficObjectAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberObservableObjectType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for an action or stateful property that occurs, or may occur, in the operational cyber environment</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableObjectName" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberObservableSocialMediaPlatformObjectType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for an object that represents the properties of a network domain name data type for a social media platform that is the subject of an observation</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberObservableObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableObjectValueText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberObservableSubNetworkObjectType">
    <xs:annotation>

    </xs:annotation>

    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberObservableURLObjectType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for an object that represents the properties of a uniform resource locator (URL) that is the subject of an observation</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberObservableObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberObservableObjectValueText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberOriginalNotifierType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for an entity who provided the original notification of a potential incident.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:OriginalAgencyNotifier" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:OriginalPersonNotifier" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:NotifyingAgencyCategoryCode" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:NotificationReasonDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:NotificationPromptedReasonDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:NotifyingAgencyCategoryCodeDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberOriginalNotifierAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="CyberTacticCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the specific tactical goal and reason why an actor performs a technique or sub-technique.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0001 - Initial Access">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to get into your network.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0002 - Execution">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to run malicious code.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0003 - Persistence">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to maintain their foothold.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0004 - Privilege Escalation">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to gain higher-level permissions.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0005 - Defense Evasion">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to avoid being detected.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0006 - Credential Access">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to steal account names and passwords.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0007 - Discovery">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0008 - Lateral Movement">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to move through your environment.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0009 - Collection">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to gather data of interest to their goal.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0010 - Exfiltration">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to steal data.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0011 - Command and Control">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to communicate with compromised systems to control them.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0040 - Impact">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to manipulate, interrupt, or destroy your systems and data.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0042 - Resource Development">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to establish resources they can use to support operations.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="TA0043 - Reconnaissance">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The adversary is trying to gather information they can use to plan future operations.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberTacticCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the specific tactical goal and reason why an actor performs a technique or sub-technique.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:CyberTacticCodeSimpleType">
        <xs:attributeGroup ref="structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberTacticType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the tactical goal and reason why an actor performs a technique or sub-technique.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberTacticCode" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberTacticOtherDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:CyberTacticAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="CyberTechniqueType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the representation of 'how' an adversary achieves a tactical goal by performing an action.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">

        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>

  <xs:simpleType name="ExchangePolicyInformationEncryptionCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a policy governing the encryption of information when retransmitted by the recipient</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="May Encrypt">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MAY encrypt the information received when it is retransmitted or redistributed. Software implementations MAY ensure that any information retransmitted is encrypted during transit to an adequate level of encryption, as defined in the protocol that uses IEP.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Must Encrypt">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MUST encrypt the information received when it is retransmitted or redistributed. Software implementations MUST ensure that any information retransmitted is encrypted during transit to an adequate level of encryption, as defined in the protocol that uses IEP.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="ExchangePolicyInformationEncryptionCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a policy governing the encryption of information when retransmitted by the recipient</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:ExchangePolicyInformationEncryptionCodeSimpleType">
        <xs:attributeGroup ref="structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="ExchangePolicyInformationProviderAttributionCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a policy governing the attribution of the information provider when redistributing the information received</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="May Attribute">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MAY directly attribute the Provider when redistributing the information received</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Must Attribute">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MUST directly attribute the Provider when redistributing the information received</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Must Not Attribute">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MUST NOT directly attribute the Provider when redistributing the information received</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="ExchangePolicyInformationProviderAttributionCodeType">

    </xs:annotation>

      </xs:extension>

  <xs:simpleType name="ExchangePolicyInformationResaleCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a policy governing the resale of information received by the recipient</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="May Resell">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MAY resell the information received</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Must Not Resell">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MUST NOT resell the information received unmodified or in a semantically equivalent format</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>

      </xs:extension>

  <xs:simpleType name="ExchangePolicyNotificationCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a statement of whether an affected entity may be notified of a compromise or threat or not</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="May Notify">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MAY notify affected parties of a potential compromise or threat</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Must Not Notify">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MUST NOT notify affected parties of potential compromise or threat</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="ExchangePolicyNotificationCodeType">

    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>

      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="ExchangePolicyPermittedActionCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of permitted action or use of information that can be taken by a recipient</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Contact For Instruction">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MUST contact the Providers before acting upon the information received. An example is where information redacted by the Provider could be derived by the Recipient and identify the affected parties</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Externally Visible Direct Actions">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MAY conduct direct, or active, actions on the information received that are externally visible</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Externally Visible Indirect Actions">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MAY conduct indirect, or passive, actions on the information received that are externally visible and MUST NOT conduct direct, or active, actions</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Internally Visible Actions">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MAY conduct actions on the information received that are only visible on the Recipient's internal networks and systems,and MUST NOT conduct actions that are visible outside of the Recipients networks and systems, or visible to third parties</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="None">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Recipients MUST NOT act upon the information received</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="ExchangePolicyPermittedActionCategoryCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of permitted action or use of information that can be taken by a recipient</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:ExchangePolicyPermittedActionCategoryCodeSimpleType">

      </xs:extension>

  <xs:simpleType name="IncidentConsequenceCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of consequence resulting from an incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Demonstrable Harm to Civil Liberties">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that is likely to result in demonstrable harm to civil liberties of the American people</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Demonstrable Harm to Economy">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that is likely to result in demonstrable harm to the economy of the United States</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Demonstrable Harm to Foreign Relations">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that is likely to result in demonstrable harm to foreign relations of the United States</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Demonstrable Harm to National Security Interests">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that is likely to result in demonstrable harm to national security interests of the United States</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Demonstrable Harm to Public Confidence">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that is likely to result in demonstrable harm to public confidence of the American people</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Demonstrable Harm to Public Health and Safety">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that is likely to result in demonstrable harm to the public health and safety of the American people</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Imminent Threat of Violation">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that constitutes an imminent threat of violation of law, security policies, security procedures, or acceptable use policies</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Violation">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>An occurrence of an incident that constitutes a violation of law, security policies, security procedures, or acceptable use policies</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="IncidentConsequenceCategoryCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of consequence resulting from an incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>

  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="IncidentConsequenceType">

      <xs:documentation>A data type for the series of details about the consequences of an incident.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceCategoryCode" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceRecoverabilityAssessmentDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceRecoverabilityEstimatedDuration" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceRecoverabilityActualDuration" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceContractsDescriptionText" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceContractsBreachIndicator" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentConsequenceAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="IncidentContainmentCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the category code for the description of the containment of the incident.</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="complete">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Containment is fully complete.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="not required">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Containment is not required.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="not started">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Containment is not started.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="ongoing">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Containment is ongoing.</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="IncidentContainmentCategoryCodeType">

    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="IncidentFunctionalImpactSeverityCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the level of severity of the functional impact of an incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Denial of Critical Services/Loss of Control">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A critical system has been rendered unavailable</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Denial of Non-Critical Services">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A non-critical system is denied or destroyed</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Minimal Impact to Critical Services">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Minimal impact but to a critical system or service, such as email or active directory</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Minimal Impact to Non-Critical Services">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Some small level of impact to non-critical systems and services</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="No Impact">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Event has no impact</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="No Impact to Services">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The event has no impact to any business or industrial control systems (ICS) services or delivery to customers</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Significant Impact to Critical Services">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A critical system has a significant impact, such as local administrative account compromise</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Significant Impact to Non-Critical Services">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A non-critical service or system has a significant impact</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="IncidentFunctionalImpactSeverityCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the level of severity of the functional impact of an incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:IncidentFunctionalImpactSeverityCodeSimpleType">
        <xs:attributeGroup ref="structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>

    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:complexType name="IncidentInfectedDeviceType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the kind of device infected by a cyber incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:complexContent>
      <xs:extension base="structures:ObjectType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentInfectedDeviceInitialIndicator" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

          <xs:element ref="cyber:Hardware" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:InfectedDeviceConnectionIndicator" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
          <xs:element ref="cyber:IncidentInfectedDeviceAugmentationPoint" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:complexContent>
  </xs:complexType>
  <xs:simpleType name="IncidentInformationalImpactSeverityCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the level of severity of the informational impact of an incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Core Credential Compromise">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Core system credentials (such as domain or enterprise administrative credentials) or credentials for critical systems have been exfiltrated</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Critical Systems Data Breach">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Data pertaining to a critical system has been exfiltrated</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Destruction of Critical System">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Destructive techniques, such as MBR overwrite, have been used against a critical system</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Destruction of Non-Critical Systems">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Destructive techniques (such as master boot record [MBR] overwrite) have been used against a non-critical system</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="No Impact">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>No known data impact</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Privacy Data Breach">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The confidentiality of Personally Identifiable Information or personal health information was compromised</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Proprietary Information Breach">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>The confidentiality of unclassified proprietary information, such as protected critical infrastructure information, intellectual property, or trade secrets was compromised</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Suspected, But Not Identified">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A data loss or impact to availability is suspected, but no direct confirmation exists</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
  <xs:complexType name="IncidentInformationalImpactSeverityCodeType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for the level of severity of the informational impact of an incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="cyber:IncidentInformationalImpactSeverityCodeSimpleType">
        <xs:attributeGroup ref="structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup"/>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>

  <xs:simpleType name="IncidentNotifiedEntityCategoryCodeSimpleType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A data type for a kind of entity notified of an incident</xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:restriction base="xs:token">
      <xs:enumeration value="Attorney General Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Attorney General has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Information Owners Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Information Owner has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Information Sharing and Analysis Center / Organization (ISAC / ISAO) Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>ISAC or ISAO has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Inspector General Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Inspector General has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Insurance Company Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>

        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Law Enforcement Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Law Enforcement has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Legal Counsel Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Legal Counsel has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Other Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>A previously unspecified entity have been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Political Leadership Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Political Leadership has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Privacy Officials Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Privacy Official has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Security Staff Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Security Staff has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="System Owners Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>System Owner has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
      <xs:enumeration value="Vendor Notified Flag">
        <xs:annotation>
          <xs:documentation>Vendor has been notified of the incident</xs:documentation>
        </xs:annotation>
      </xs:enumeration>
    </xs:restriction>
  </xs:simpleType>
